name: sfchronicle
text:
Three people traveling in a black Mercedes Sprinter van are arrested after shots are allegedly fired from the vehicle at a fully marked CHP vehicle carrying two officers assigned to Hayward.

Story by @SamWhitingSF: https://t.co/g9WsVFN0ET

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SantiagoMejia: California Highway Patrol cruisers whipping by and now seeing CHP in riot gear jogging on foot on upper level of #SanFrancisco #BayBridge to an apparent caravan protest. @sfchronicle https://t.co/fJXpKfPfTNCalifornia Highway Patrol cruisers whipping by and now seeing CHP in riot gear jogging on foot on upper level of… https://t.co/18FKwPPxWk

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: Protesters shut down westbound Bay Bridge. https://t.co/KWPa0HSVfd https://t.co/veax5zxdFk

name: sfchronicle
text:
BREAKING: Bay Bridge westbound lanes shut down by protest; California Highway Patrol making arrests.

Story by @MGafni: https://t.co/UybcozhnFj

name: sfchronicle
text: @mgafni Some CHP vehicles were seen going by on the shoulder of the roadway, with sirens blaring. But due to the traffic, CHP officers had to park their patrol vehicles and walk to the scene where they were arresting protesters. https://t.co/KwxXwwGbBD https://t.co/K6O4SoptWb

name: sfchronicle
text: @mgafni UPDATE: Bay Bridge traffic begins to move after westbound lanes shut down by protesters who spray painted bridge. https://t.co/KwxXwwGbBD

name: sfchronicle
text: Coronavirus Updates: The number of confirmed COVID-19 patients in hospitals in the nine Bay Area counties was reported at 236 on Saturday, the area’s lowest total since June 4, according to state data reviewed by The Chronicle. https://t.co/NqxLQd3Bhi https://t.co/XjCJ9lle9Z

name: sfchronicle
text: Coronavirus Updates: San Francisco will resume ticketing for parking violations related to street sweeping Monday after halting enforcement of those violations in March amid the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/oRfdUdUUoJ https://t.co/Lu3ethwUOw

name: sfchronicle
text:
Vallejo spent $40,000 to hire a team of consultants to tell it what residents have been saying about the police for years.

via @OtisRTaylorJr: https://t.co/3CExxN9Y1j https://t.co/HhCADMmjfP

name: sfchronicle
text:
Don’t want a long swab up your nose? Bay Area coronavirus test sites are trying alternatives.

Story by @Cat_Ho: https://t.co/zqUVoklWPa https://t.co/7q8ZEwxi8k

name: sfchronicle
text:
The elusive key to a coronavirus vaccine, the S.F. official navigating the pandemic response, and wildfire season heats up.

Here's what you need to know to start your day: https://t.co/71spR6PEgj https://t.co/B5O7n5B0Ou

name: sfchronicle
text: The global number of confirmed cases of the coronavirus stood at 7,936,874 on Monday morning, while 2,094,069 of those people have tested positive here in the U.S. The death toll worldwide was 433,959. https://t.co/npXcUyHw1i https://t.co/aK7S8ZtPI5

name: sfchronicle
text:
Vallejo spent $40,000 to hire a team of private consultants to tell city leaders that the Vallejo Police Department had problems.

Vallejoans have been telling city leaders this for years, writes @OtisRTaylorJr. https://t.co/Tee5858qpk

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that a landmark civil rights law protects gay and lesbian people from discrimination in employment. https://t.co/bow0K1SEHv https://t.co/MhPlRUkcvx

name: sfchronicle
text:
Need to go to the doctor soon (for non-COVID reasons?) An office visit has been totally changed by the pandemic. 

Here's what to know if you're headed in for a checkup soon: https://t.co/5YMN5d044y

name: sfchronicle
text:
Total coronavirus cases
• 152,285 in California, including 5,082 deaths.
• 17,263 in the Bay Area, including 498 deaths.
• More than 2 million in the U.S., including 115,732 deaths.
• More than 7.9 million in the world, more than 433,000 deaths. https://t.co/m86Xt1J02q https://t.co/q3SMWPk7iW

name: sfchronicle
text: The U.S. Supreme Court has rejected the Trump administration’s challenge of California’s sanctuary law, which restricts law enforcement cooperation with federal immigration agents. https://t.co/leY7XxCfmu https://t.co/7rqGhZrCi6

name: sfchronicle
text: Tired of takeout? Here are some Bay Area restaurants open for outdoor dining: https://t.co/OVGje64IAK

name: sfchronicle
text: "How would I lecture with a mask on? I don’t think I’m comfortable doing that to my students.” https://t.co/bvifvfbRIl

name: sfchronicle
text: 24 Hour Fitness files for bankruptcy, closes 130 gyms, including 10 in the Bay Area. The San Ramon company said in a Chapter 11 filing that it had secured about $250 million in financing from its creditors to resume business at about 300 locations.  https://t.co/ng47LUQXbk https://t.co/KLwnM1EIs3

name: sfchronicle
text: To date, there have been no verified cases of reinfection, so it appears there is some immunity in people who have gotten sick. https://t.co/DP2EwPR8QP

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @Con_Chron: Per @IanBegley, Warriors assistant GM Mike Dunleavy Jr. is in the running for a front-office role with the Pistons: https://t.co/lEuE4k8h8q

name: sfchronicle
text:
SF has entered a new phase of reopening today. On the list: 
• Most indoor retail
• Summer camps
• Religious services, ceremonies
• Private household indoor services (house cleaning)
More info on the city's reopening timeline here: https://t.co/IsZBuFx7MH

name: sfchronicle
text: In recent weeks, many coronavirus testing sites have started using shorter, less invasive swabs that don’t go nearly as far into the nose. https://t.co/aStCPB6oZC

name: sfchronicle
text: Warriors assistant general manager Mike Dunleavy Jr. is being considered for a role in the Pistons’ front office, according to SNY. https://t.co/sIsHve5wM4

name: sfchronicle
text: San Franciscans will now be able to shop indoors, and will be able to resume more outdoor activities — up to 12 people only — with other safety requirements. This means the city is officially moving into “Phase 2B.” https://t.co/zRJ6JlYbR8 https://t.co/Css4xCdU8Z

name: sfchronicle
text: Wildfire season has arrived in California, and PG&E is again preparing to take drastic measures to prevent more catastrophes — all while the whole state is simultaneously grappling with the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/WMOxOtA9Up

name: sfchronicle
text: The Food and Drug Administration is revoking the emergency authorization for malaria drugs being used against the coronavirus as mounting evidence indicates they don’t work and could cause deadly side effects, the Associated Press reports. https://t.co/EqevyZTgt8 https://t.co/Ct8eWd13iw

name: sfchronicle
text: Arguably the most powerful public official in San Francisco during the pandemic has been a soft-spoken epidemiology expert you’ve probably never heard of before. https://t.co/82dvfE4x6V

name: sfchronicle
text:
The shorter swabs are less unpleasant and in some cases can be used to collect samples by the patients themselves.

https://t.co/mTasehRt0N

name: sfchronicle
text: Caltrans maintenance crews are trying to determine how to remove the BLM letters painted on the Bay Bridge without damaging the roadway. Spokesman Bart Ney said the agency plans to remove the paint this week. https://t.co/IwK62fS1NH https://t.co/RsGapqTZfY

name: sfchronicle
text:
University of California regents endorse a state amendment to repeal Proposition 209, the affirmative action ban approved by state voters in the 1990s. 
https://t.co/hZecD2FUsz

name: sfchronicle
text:
Due to the coronavirus pandemic, spectators will be unable to attend the PGA Championship, set to be held at San Francisco's Harding Park in early August.
https://t.co/gnk0w99zNq

name: sfchronicle
text: Demographers have long known that Democrats tend to favor wine while Republicans favor beer. https://t.co/aBZcgvXNxZ

name: sfchronicle
text:
The discovery of antibodies that block the most infectious elements of the coronavirus is helping Bay Area scientists understand human immunity, and could be crucial in the development of a vaccine.

https://t.co/2MHLhrcXtu

name: sfchronicle
text: Gov. Gavin Newsom urged Californians to "be smart" and continue wearing a face covering and practicing social distancing as the threat of the coronavirus persists. https://t.co/PjFlqXyWiA https://t.co/R0Be5NUia1

name: sfchronicle
text:
An SF man was approached while stenciling “Black Lives Matter” on the retaining wall of his Pacific Heights home. Video of the confrontation has gone viral, spurring conversation about racism and presumption of guilt.

https://t.co/xeDP0FLT4t

name: sfchronicle
text: The rate of Californians testing positive for the coronavirus is about 4.5%. In April, 41% of Californians tested positive, but far fewer people were being tested at that time. https://t.co/RJDaypHmYA

name: sfchronicle
text:
Not all police chiefs are willing to engage with the call to defund the police, but @SFPDchief William Scott tells @HKnightSF he agrees @SFPD officers’ responsibilities should be narrowed.

Spotify > https://t.co/5JV8rQfI5I https://t.co/cdQRib8Dip

name: sfchronicle
text:
Six former eBay employees were charged with harassing a Massachusetts tech newsletter editor and publisher, including sending them live cockroaches, a preserved fetal pig, a bloody pig mask and funeral wreath.

https://t.co/m6bWWBPic6

name: sfchronicle
text:
California's Attorney General calls for a statewide mechanism to decertify police officers for serious misconduct, a type of accountability long resisted in a state that prides itself on criminal justice reforms.

https://t.co/KqktihJlQ7

name: sfchronicle
text: "Gone With the Wind" can be a teachable opportunity without being taken down, @TonyBravoSF writes: https://t.co/fGeUUru7wD

name: sfchronicle
text:
Despite concerns that California could see new coronavirus outbreaks, Gov. Newsom gave a broad defense of the state's accelerated reopening strategy and says the number of people hospitalized with coronavirus-related illness has remained stable.

https://t.co/lgCsxj6PNV
